T1003.001::[Kimsuky] has gathered credentials using [Mimikatz] and ProcDump.
T1021.001::[Kimsuky] has used RDP for direct remote point-and-click access.
T1027.002::[Kimsuky] has packed malware with UPX.
T1036.004::[Kimsuky] has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions.
T1036.005::[Kimsuky] has renamed malware to legitimate names such as ESTCommon.dll or patch.dll.
T1053.005::[Kimsuky] has downloaded additional malware with scheduled tasks.
T1055.012::[Kimsuky] has used a file injector DLL to spawn a benign process on the victim's system and inject the malicious payload into it via process hollowing.
T1056.001::[Kimsuky] has used a PowerShell-based keylogger as well as a tool called MECHANICAL to log keystrokes.
T1059.001::[Kimsuky] has executed a variety of PowerShell scripts.
T1059.003::[Kimsuky] has executed Windows commands by using `cmd` and running batch scripts.
T1059.005::[Kimsuky] has used Visual Basic to download malicious payloads.
T1059.006::[Kimsuky] has used a macOS Python implant to gather data as well as MailFetcher.py code to automatically collect email data.
T1059.007::[Kimsuky] has used JScript for logging and downloading additional tools.

T1070.004::[Kimsuky] has deleted the exfiltrated data on disk after transmission. [Kimsuky] has also used an instrumentor script to terminate browser processes running on an infected system and then delete the cookie files on disk.
T1070.006::[Kimsuky] has manipulated timestamps for creation or compilation dates to defeat anti-forensics.
T1071.001::[Kimsuky]  has used HTTP GET and POST requests for C2.
T1071.002::[Kimsuky] has used FTP to download additional malware to the target machine.
T1071.003::[Kimsuky] has used e-mail to send exfiltrated data to C2 servers.
T1074.001::[Kimsuky] has staged collected data files under C:\Program Files\Common Files\System\Ole DB\.
T1078.003::[Kimsuky] has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP.
T1102.002::[Kimsuky] has used Blogspot pages for C2.
T1114.002::[Kimsuky] has used tools such as the MailFetch mail crawler to collect victim emails (excluding spam) from online services via IMAP.
T1114.003::[Kimsuky] has set auto-forward rules on victim's e-mail accounts.
T1136.001::[Kimsuky] has created accounts with net user.
T1204.001::[Kimsuky] has lured victims into clicking malicious links.
T1204.002::[Kimsuky] has used attempted to lure victims into opening malicious e-mail attachments.
T1218.005::[Kimsuky] has used mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system.
T1218.010::[Kimsuky] has executed malware with regsvr32s.
T1218.011::[Kimsuky] has used `rundll32.exe` to execute malicious scripts and malware on a victim's network.
T1505.003::[Kimsuky] has used modified versions of open source PHP web shells to maintain access, often adding "Dinosaur" references within the code.
T1518.001::[Kimsuky] has checked for the presence of antivirus software with powershell Get-CimInstance -Namespace root/securityCenter2 â€“ classname antivirusproduct.
T1543.003::[Kimsuky] has created new services for persistence.
T1546.001::[Kimsuky] has a HWP document stealer module which changes the default program association in the registry to open HWP documents.
T1547.001::[Kimsuky] has placed scripts in the startup folder for persistence and modified the `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce` Registry key.
T1550.002::[Kimsuky] has used pass the hash for authentication to remote access software used in C2.
T1552.001::[Kimsuky] has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.
T1553.002::[Kimsuky] has signed files with the name EGIS CO,. Ltd..

T1555.003::[Kimsuky] has used browser extensions including Google Chrome to steal passwords and cookies from browsers. [Kimsuky] has also used Nirsoft's WebBrowserPassView tool to dump the passwords obtained from victims.
T1560.001::[Kimsuky] has used QuickZip to archive stolen files before exfiltration.
T1560.003::[Kimsuky] has used RC4 encryption before exfil.
T1562.001::[Kimsuky] has been observed turning off Windows Security Center and can hide the AV software window from the view of the infected user.
T1562.004::[Kimsuky] has been observed disabling the system firewall.
T1564.002::[Kimsuky] has run reg add â€˜HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserListâ€™ /v to hide a newly created user.
T1564.003::[Kimsuky] has used an information gathering module that will hide an AV software window from the victim.
T1566.001::[Kimsuky] has used emails containing Word, Excel and/or HWP (Hangul Word Processor) documents in their spearphishing campaigns.
T1566.002::[Kimsuky] has sent spearphishing emails containing a link to a document that contained malicious macros or took the victim to an actor-controlled domain.
T1567.002::[Kimsuky] has exfiltrated stolen files and data to actor-controlled Blogspot accounts.
T1583.001::[Kimsuky] has registered domains to spoof targeted organizations and trusted third parties.
T1583.004::[Kimsuky] has purchased hosting servers with virtual currency and prepaid cards.
T1583.006::[Kimsuky] has hosted content used for targeting efforts via web services such as Blogspot.
T1584.001::[Kimsuky] has compromised legitimate sites and used them to distribute malware.
T1585.001::[Kimsuky] has created social media accounts to monitor news and security trends as well as potential targets.
T1585.002::[Kimsuky] has created email accounts for phishing operations.
T1586.002::[Kimsuky] has compromised email accounts to send spearphishing e-mails.
T1587.001::[Kimsuky] has developed its own unique malware such as MailFetch.py for use in operations.
T1588.002::[Kimsuky] has obtained and used tools such as Nirsoft WebBrowserPassVIew, [Mimikatz], and [PsExec].
T1588.005::[Kimsuky] has obtained exploit code for various CVEs.
T1589.002::[Kimsuky] has collected valid email addresses that were subsequently used in spearphishing campaigns.
T1589.003::[Kimsuky] has collected victim employee name information.
T1593.001::[Kimsuky] has used Twitter to monitor potential victims and to prepare targeted phishing e-mails.
T1593.002::[Kimsuky] has searched for vulnerabilities, tools, and geopolitical trends on Google to target victims.
T1598.003::[Kimsuky] has used links in e-mail to steal account information.
T1608.001::[Kimsuky] has used Blogspot to host malicious content such as beacons, file exfiltrators, and implants.
